awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Ferroelectric Memristive Devices Emulating Synapses in Subcortical Information Processors
awd_abstract_narration:
Neuromorphic computing is an interdisciplinary field that aspires to create physical architecture and design principles based on biological nervous systems for applications in vision systems, auditory systems and autonomous robots.  There is an increasing interest in developing electronic analog circuits to mimic neuro-biological architectures present in the nervous system.  In the nervous system of the brain, a synapse is a structure that permits a neuron to pass an electrical or chemical signal to another cell. This exploratory research proposes to create a two-terminal memristive device that can emulate the function of a synapse. The resistance of the device will change depending on the amount, direction, and duration of voltage applied. The device has advantage of maintaining its state until another voltage pulse is applied over conventional computer memory, which requires regular charge to maintain its state.  The principle behind the proposed approach is to make dipoles in a film switch up or down depending on voltage polarity in ferroelectric materials. If the thickness of the ferroelectric layer is made small enough, it can allow tunneling of electrons that is a function of the relative density of dipoles in up or down position thus preserving a memory similar to that of the synapse, thereby making electronic analog circuits to mimic brain. The proposed novel synapse circuits will enable integration of complex systems with power-constrained devices. The research on hafnium oxide (HfO2) based FTJ will also open the door for further scaling of FE capacitor based random access memory and enable the fabrication of FE field effect transistor (FE-FET) based memory. The graduate students would have a significant opportunity in advancing their interdisciplinary skills in semiconductors device design and fabrication, integrated circuit design, machine learning, and neuroscience.  

This proposal explores a two-terminal memristive device based on newly discovered ferroelectricity in CMOS compatible high permittivity dielectric, HfO2 doped with silicon or aluminum.   The switching mechanism in FTJ is driven by polarization that is relatively immune from stochastic variations observed in other resistive memory devices. Fabrication of a high permittivity HfO2 based ferroelectric device will allow thinner films which can be scaled. The goal of the proposed research is to explore the design and fabrication of HfO2 based ferroelectric tunnel junction (FTJ) memristive device and its characterization to generate models. In addition, neuron circuits with multiple signaling types for behavioral emulation of biological neurons will be designed, synaptic circuits based on the proposed memristor device models will be trained, and the feasibility of incorporating the neuron and synapse circuits into subcortex-inspired information processing (SIIP) system will be evaluated. The outcome of the proposed exploratory research will result in a novel device that can mimic synaptic behavior and can be integrated with conventional CMOS electronics thereby forming the basis for the next generation of intelligent computing.

por.por_cntn:
Neuromorphic computing is an interdisciplinary field that aspires to create physical architecture and design principles based on biological nervous systems for applications such as vision systems, auditory systems and autonomous robots.  There is an increasing interest in developing electronic analog circuits to mimic neuro-biological architectures present in the nervous system.  In the nervous system of the brain, a synapse is a structure that permits a neuron to pass an electrical or chemical signal to another cell. This proposed exploratory research will create a device that can emulate this function of the synapse.

A memristor is a two-terminal device whose resistance changes depending on the amount, direction, and duration of voltage that is applied to it. Furthermore, whatever its past state, or resistance is, it freezes that state until another voltage is applied to change it and maintaining that state requires no power. This is different from a conventional computer memory, which requires regular charge to maintain its state. Many different forms of memristor devices are being explored each relying on different mechanism such as moving oxygen bubbles or ions between electrodes, or creating conducting filaments.  Another way is to make dipoles in a film switch up or down depending on voltage polarity which is observed in ferroelectric materials. If the thickness of the ferroelectric layer is made small enough, it can allow tunneling of electrons that is a function of the relative density of dipoles in up or down position thus preserving a memory similar to that of the synapse.  Creating this device will enable making electronic analog circuits to mimic the brain.

This proposal constituted an exploratory work on newly discovered (2013-14) ferroelectricity in CMOS compatible high permittivity dielectric, HfO2 doped with silicon or aluminum.   The goal of the proposed research was to explore the design and fabrication of a HfO2 based ferroelectric tunnel junction (FTJ) memristive device and its application in neuromorphic systems.  The switching mechanism in FTJ is driven by polarization that is relatively immune from stochastic variations observed in other resistive memory devices.  Two terminal FEJ devices are fabricated and electrically characterized to generate models.

This research has provided a steppingstone to the next generation of intelligent computing, which is envisioned as the product of a collaborative effort between device design and fabrication, integrated circuit design, machine learning, and neuroscience scientists and engineers.  It is natural that intelligent computing systems should borrow abstract design concepts from the human nervous system, and this has been a common theme seen in research from the neuromorphic community.  In this study the synapse-like properties of FTJ memristive devices are investigated to design computing systems which are influenced by the behavior of subcortical brain regions. 

The research on HfO2 based FTJ has opened the door for further scaling of FE capacitor based random access memory and enable the fabrication of FE field effect transistor (FE-FET) based memory.

Intellectual Merits

The proposal constituted an exploratory work on newly discovered (2013-14) ferroelectricity in CMOS compatible high-k dielectric – doped HfO2 with an aim to develop a synaptic memristive device.  The research is interdisciplinary and spans across research in the areas of devices, integrated circuit design, machine learning, and neuroscience.  Investigation from memristive device to SIIP system makes the research a fundamentally challenging pursuit.   Ferroelectric device fabrication and test infrastructure resulted from this work including an international collaboration.

Broader Impacts

Successful implementation of the work in systems will have a transformative impact on the emerging field of synaptic electronics. The research will also open the door for further (DRAM-like) scaling of FE capacitor based random access memory (F-RAM) and enable the fabrication of FE field effect transistor (FE-FET) based memory, combining the performance and the established reliability of FE-RAM with a small NAND-Flash cell.  One PhD and three Master’s thesis have emerged from this work.  Five undergraduate students have participated in this research.  The research has been integrated into two courses – quantum and solid state devices and neuromorphic computing.
